entry.title: SF Concurrent Employment - Custom MDF
entry.content:
Hey everyone!
 
I currently have a client who has a strong presence of concurrent employment within their organization. In their practice, they have two types of "concurrent" employees as we know it:
  1. Employees who truly work 2 different positions with different attributes (standard concurrent)
  2. Employees who work different positions and/or location where their key position attributes are the same (ie. someone holds the same position at 2,3,4 or more different locations; or someone 2 different positions at the same location but the position attributes relevant to time, pay, etc. are the same)
In scenario 1, the SuccessFactors Concurrent Employment setup will suffice and is necessary for the purpose of have 2 defined positions in the Org Chart and 2 timesheets. However, in scenario 2, we are presented with a couple of key challenges below: 
  • Multiple position maintenance (ie. HR will be required to create a position in the Org chart for every position/location combination)
  • Multiple profiles and timesheets (1 per assignment), causing a complex end user experience, and potential rounding issues
 
We are reviewing and looking at the use of a custom MDF to handle the positions for  employees within scenario 2 where the key attributes are the same to improve these challenges.
 
If anyone has encountered similar experiences with this type of concurrent employee and has found this custom MDF option to work well, I would love to hear your experiences, limitations encountered, and potential challenges/impacts related to upgrades, and/or new product releases. Any insights related to EC, Time, Payroll,  Recruiting, Onboarding, and Integrations would be greatly appreciated. 
 
Thanks so much!

entry.title: Re: I need to list multiple datetime values from a single...
entry.content:
Hello @jwagner 

Glad to hear the formula is almost working üòä

To clean it up so it only shows the date like June 4, 2025 without the 12:00:00 AM part, you just need to wrap the date in the DateValue function. That strips off the time.

Here‚Äôs a quick example,

Totext(DateValue(?YourDateParameter), "MMMM d, yyyy")

If your parameter allows multiple dates, and you want to list them all nicely formatted, you can do something like this:

Local StringVar result := "";
Local NumberVar i;

For i := 1 To Count(?YourDateParameter) Do
(
result := result + Totext(DateValue(?YourDateParameter[i]), "MMMM d, yyyy") + ", ";
);

Left(result, Length(result) - 2)

With this, it will go through all the dates you have selected, tidy up the formatting to show just the dates (without the time), and give you a nice, clean list comma-separated for easy reading

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Best practices for keeping up with the SAP Activate content updates
entry.content:
In this post, I intend to share practices and resources that will help you stay in step with the rapid and regular updates in the SAP Activate road maps that SAP delivers to our customers both on the SAP Activate road map viewer (link) and in the SAP Cloud ALM application. We deliver these updates to keep the implementation guidance in step with the innovations introduced in the product and to give our users the latest, up-to-date guidance and accelerators that help them run their transformation projects better. Most of our road maps are on a bi-weekly update cycle, and in some updates, we deliver minor refinements of the content that users may not even notice, while in other updates, we introduce significant updates to support our users in adopting new capabilities.

For example earlier in this year when SAP released Parallel Line capability to all our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public customers on 3-system landscape, the SAP Activate guidance delivered several new tasks and accelerators to help our users to learn about this new capability, request provisioning of the parallel line tenants and explanation on how to use this functionality for parallel configuration activities and how to use transports in this parallel line. There are also examples for the SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private, where some of our latest additions were bringing the guidance for use of WalkMe, refinement of the Clean Core Quality Gates, and new content for RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard. To name just a few.

Now, how can we best keep up with these ongoing updates? There are two main sources for information, one in each of our tools, where SAP delivers SAP Activate to our users. Let‚Äôs start with the SAP Activate in the road map viewer.

Release notes in the SAP Activate road map viewer

For the most frequently updated SAP Activate road maps, like SAP Activate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP Activate for SAP Cloud ERP Private, you can find dedicated release notes on the Overview page of the road map in the application. See the screenshot below with the highlighted section where you can access the release notes.

When you open the link, you will download a document with release notes that are updated every time we release a new update. These notes provide an overview of the key updates delivered with the new content release. This document is a great source for staying up to date with the new content delivered in each update. You can review it on a regular basis to stay up to date on all the key updates delivered in the SAP Activate road map.

Detailed content update summary in SAP Cloud ALM

Users of SAP Cloud ALM may have noticed a tile ‚ÄúSAP Content Update Summary‚Äù in the Project Overview app (see the screenshot below). The tile provides detailed information about how many tasks have been updated (blue bubble), how many new tasks were delivered in the content update (light gray bubble), and how many tasks have been deprecated (dark gray bubble).

The user can click on each bubble to go to the detailed task list for each category (see the screenshot below). In this screen, you can open the task details by selecting it, assess whether it is relevant to your project, and accordingly assign it to the user or team. If it is not relevant, mark it as such with the status ‚ÄúNot Relevant.‚Äù

Now, let‚Äôs look at the ‚ÄúUpdated‚Äù tasks. We will access the task list the same way we did in the previous step from the Project Overview screen. Then, in the list, we can pick one task to review the details of the change. You will access the ‚ÄúHistory‚Äù details by selecting the ‚Äú‚Ä¶‚Äù at the top right side of the screen and selecting the ‚ÄúHistory‚Äù item from the menu (see below).

The history opens to the right of the task. In this section of the screen, you can select the time frame for the history (filter button on the right) or change the sorting how the history is shown (sort button on the left). The sorting will present the history from the latest changes at the top (default) or you can change it to see the oldest changes at the top.

This way, you can see all the detailed changes of the content that have been delivered to your project. Like in the example for new tasks, you can assess if the updated task is relevant for your project and if the assigned owner can carry it out. Use the Status and Comments on the task to keep track of your actions and communication with the task owner.

Note that this capability works for both projects created with single SAP Activate roadmap as well as the projects utilizing combined roadmaps in SAP Cloud ALM. In our example, we used a combined roadmap with content from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3-system landscape, SAP SuccessFactors, the Adoption Plan for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and SAP Concur.

I hope that this blog post helped you understand how to best utilize the release notes and detailed content history in SAP Cloud ALM to keep yourself up to date on the release updates and your project task list. Please share your feedback in the comments and let me know if you already use these features and what your experience is.

entry.title: How to analyze thread dumps in SAP Commerce Cloud
entry.content:
Is your SAP Commerce Cloud feeling sluggish?

If you've seen the dreaded "Tomcat Thread Available Percentage Low"  alert pop up in Dynatrace, you're not alone. In this article, we‚Äôll walk you through how to dive into thread dumps and uncover the clues you need to solve those performance mysteries.

First thing we need to understand is what is a thread dump?

A thread dump is basically a freeze-frame of everything the application‚Äôs threads are doing at a specific moment. It shows details like the thread's state, ID, name, stack trace, priority, and more. But since it's just a single snapshot, it won‚Äôt always tell the whole story. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs a good idea to collect a series of thread dumps taken close together, ideally while the issue (like CPU saturation) is actually happening. Looking at them in sequence helps you spot patterns and understand what the application was really up to during the slowdown.

Thread state includes:

  • NEW
    A thread that has not yet started is in this state.
  • RUNNABLE
    A thread executing in the Java virtual machine is in this state.
  • BLOCKED
    A thread that is blocked waiting for a monitor lock is in this state.
  • WAITING
    A thread that is waiting indefinitely for another thread to perform a particular action is in this state.
  • TIMED_WAITING
    A thread that is waiting for another thread to perform an action for up to a specified waiting time is in this state.
  • TERMINATED
    A thread that has exited is in this state.

How to collect a thread dump?

There are several ways to collect this piece of evidence, please find below all of them listed:

  • Continuous thread profiling in Dynatrace is one of the simplest ways to keep an eye on thread usage‚Äîmainly because you don‚Äôt need to catch the issue in the act. Since profiling runs all the time, you can go back and review what was happening even after the problem has passed. Just head over to ‚ÄúProfiling & Optimization‚Äù in Dynatrace and click on ‚ÄúContinuous CPU Profiling‚Äù to dig into the details.



    Once you're on the CPU profiling page, find the service where the issue occurred. Click the three dots next to it and choose ‚ÄúThreads‚Äù to take a closer look.

    Next, you'll land on the Threads Breakdown page. Here, you‚Äôll need to pick the thread group you want to analyze. In general, when troubleshooting SAP Commerce Cloud issues, the "hybrisHTTP" thread group is a good place to start, since it's responsible for handling most of the core operations. That said, the relevant thread group might vary depending on the issue. For example, if you're looking into slowness during a Synchronization task, the thread name will be different.

    But for now, let‚Äôs stick with hybrisHTTP. Click the three dots next to it and choose ‚ÄúMethod hotspots‚Äù to dive deeper.

    The Methods Hotspots page will appear, showing thread states along with a chart that displays the number of threads and estimated CPU time. You can expand individual methods based on their contribution to explore more detailed information.



  • Thread Dump collector in HAC can be used in case your project has HAC endpoint enabled in the service where the problem is identified. For example, if you are troubleshooting issues with API the HAC endpoint must be enabled in API service so you can access it over API URL. To trigger a thread dump from there you firstly need to access HAC and open developer tools > application tab > change the value of ROUTE cookie for the problematic pod. In this case let's say the pod facing the problem is the backgroundprocessing-7887d8b7cc-1234, we should place this as the value of the cookie such as ".backgroundprocessing-7887d8b7cc-1234". Check the screenshot below:

    Refresh the page and make sure the value of ROUTE cookie remains the same. Now we can trigger the dump from the correct pod. Go to Monitoring Tab > Thread Dump and then download the dump file, just like demonstrated in the screenshot below:
    ‚ÄÉ

    "Record Dumps" tab gives you the possibility to select thread dumps over a period of time. You can select in which time periods the thread dumps are being collected so you can have several dump files to analyze execution over time. When you click stop, the thread dumps will be downloaded as zip File.
    Additionally, one of my peers developed a great groovy script for thread dumps in SAP Commerce Cloud, you can also consider this option by checking his blog post Groovy Solution for Commerce Thread Dumps.


  • In case none of the options above works in your case you can still contact SAP Commerce Cloud Technical Support team through a ticket requesting thread dumps, they have special scripts ready to trigger thread dumps from any pod. This option is only useful if technical support team is able to catch the issue at the time it is happening and trigger the dump. To analyze thread exhaustions that happened in the past, please check the first option listed in this article.

Having the thread dumps at hand is time to analyze the content of it.

Once you‚Äôve collected your thread dumps, it‚Äôs time to dig in and figure out what‚Äôs going on under the hood. Thread dumps give you a snapshot of all the threads running in your application at a specific point in time, is really useful when you‚Äôre trying to troubleshoot performance problems, deadlocks, or resource issues.

  1. First things first, start by opening the thread dump file in a text editor you‚Äôre comfortable with, something like VS Code (which I most like), IntelliJ, or even Notepad++. These tools make it easier to search and navigate through large and multiple files.

  2. Do a quick search for: "java.lang.Thread.State: BLOCKED"  text. This will show you all the threads that are currently blocked, meaning they‚Äôre waiting for access to a locked resource.

  3. Once you find them, here‚Äôs what to look for:

    1. Count How Many Threads Are Blocked
      If you notice a large number of threads in a blocked state, it could mean that they‚Äôre all waiting for the same resource that‚Äôs being held by one thread. This is often a sign of a bottleneck or even a potential deadlock.

    2. Look at the Stack Trace of the Blocked Threads
      Check out what each thread was doing when it got blocked. The stack trace will show you exactly where in the code it was. If you see multiple threads stuck on the same line or in the same method, that‚Äôs definitely a red flag.
      Example:

      "hybrisHTTP2-14" #58 prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007f7b6c0f2000 nid=0x61a5 waiting for monitor entry [0x00007f7b42fd4000]
         java.lang.Thread.State: BLOCKED (on object monitor)
      at de.hybris.platform.servicelayer.internal.model.impl.DefaultModelService.save(DefaultModelService.java:420)
      - waiting to lock <0x00000000d5a1fc58> (a java.lang.Object)
      at com.mycompany.core.service.impl.MyCustomService.performSomething(MyCustomService.java:123)
      This tells us that the thread is blocked trying to save something through ModelService, and it‚Äôs waiting to get a lock on a shared object.

    3. Find the Thread That‚Äôs Holding the Lock
      Once you‚Äôve identified the lock object (in this case, <0x00000000d5a1fc58>), search the dump for "- locked <0x00000000d5a1fc58>" text. That will show you which thread actually has the lock and is blocking the others. This is super helpful for pointing the root cause.

  4. Not all problems come from blocked threads, sometimes threads just run for too long. These could be stuck in inefficient code, long database queries, or waiting on external systems.
    Search for threads in this state: "java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE". Look specially for the ones with large stacktraces.
    Example:
    "hybrisHTTP3-22" #78 prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007f7b6d8c2000 nid=0x62d0 runnable [0x00007f7b420d3000]
       java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
    at java.util.regex.Pattern$GroupHead.match(Pattern.java:4710)
    at com.mycompany.facades.search.impl.MySearchFacade.filterResults(MySearchFacade.java:200)
    In this case, the thread might be stuck in a regex-heavy loop while filtering search results‚Äîsomething that could slow down the system significantly.

  5. If you‚Äôve collected several thread dumps (say, at 10-second intervals), compare them side by side. Look for patterns like:

    • The same threads being blocked every time
    • A growing number of blocked threads
    • A specific thread always holding the same lock

    These clues will help you spot persistent issues versus one-off hiccups.

Final Thoughts

Thread dumps can feel overwhelming, but if you follow this process, starting with blocked threads, checking who‚Äôs holding locks, and spotting long-running operations, you can uncover the root causes of many performance problems in SAP Commerce Cloud.

entry.title: Re: Escalation Email for Pending Approvals in SAP Busines...
entry.content:
Hello Jaralban, 

Yes like said before, you can go to Business Task Management for Purchase Request and Order Management in Business Configuration work center fine tuning activity. Under Purchase Order, Select the task type Purchase Order Approver, on the right side, you can define the due date for the approval task. Also select - If the task is not completed on time, the system reaction is: Create Escalation Task Type. 

Further in Home work center - Inbox view- Click on Subscribe to Tasks - Managing My Area - Operational Purchasing - Make sure user selects - Escalation: Approve Purchase Order must be selected.  This will make system to automatically trigger the escalation task.

Relevance:
The task is relevant to the Reporting Line Unit Manager of that employee who is assigned to the approval task. The manager receives this task in the Inbox sub view of the Work view of the Home work center.

Hope this helps.

Best Regards,
Arun

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 1: Introduction to Data Products
entry.content:
Introduction:

Data products are the foundation of SAP Business Data Cloud, serving as the core building blocks of the platform. Each data product is a curated package of business process data and its associated semantics, metadata, harmonized and replicated from SAP applications like SAP S/4HANA, SAP Ariba, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Concur, etc. SAP handles the entire replication process, ensuring data is reliable and consistent. For example, a Sales order data product contains mainly 2 entities, Sales order and Sales order item, and all relevant fields like order number, customer, product, quantity, and delivery date. Beyond raw table data (VBAK, VBAP) , metadata plays a critical role‚Äîit adds meaning, context, and relationships between data elements, such as linking a product to its supplier or defining its description in multiple languages.

This blog series explores:

  • What are data products? What are the data packages ?
  • Why do we need data products instead of tables ?
  • What types of data products exist? 
  • Difference between data products?
  • How to extend, create, or manage them?
  • What benefits do data products bring to your data strategy?
  1. SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 1: Introduction to Data Products.
  2. SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 2: Extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products.
  3. SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 3: Customer-Managed Data Products Coming soon....

üîçWhat Are Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud?

Data products are core building blocks within SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). They are curated data sets that include both raw business data and rich metadata, harmonized and replicated from SAP source systems. These data products are designed to be easily consumable, reusable, and trusted sources of truth across analytical and business applications. Crucially, Data Products are fully governed and made available via APIs and a Data Product Directory, allowing them to be easily discovered and used across the organization.

Each data product is self-describing, meaning it includes not only the data itself but also metadata such as:

  • Interface definitions for data extraction
  • Delta-load capabilities
  • Technical documentation
  • Semantic and relationship details (e.g., Product ID with descriptions, supplier info, customer info, currency, unit of measure etc.)

üß± Types of Data Products

SAP BDC supports three types of data products, based on ownership and development:

  • SAP-Managed Data Products: Delivered and maintained by SAP. These are standardized and regularly updated as the source application evolves.
  • Derived Data Products: Curated by SAP and built by leveraging existing Data Products.
  • Customer-Managed Data Products: Created by customers to suit their specific data needs.
    • Custom Data Products: Example would be created based on the Z CDS entities or non-SAP data loaded into the SAP Datasphere Object Store.
    • SAP BW Data Product Generator: SAP BW 7.5 or BW/4HANA Private Cloud feature, this pushes data to the SAP Datasphere Object Store. Created local tables can be shared as data products (Via Data sharing Cockpit).
  • Partner-Managed Data Products: Built by SAP partners, often tailored for industry-specific use cases.
  • 3rd Party Data Products: Built and managed by 3rd party partner. Delivered to SAP Datasphere tenants via Data Marketplace. Can be licensed for free or at cost defined by the 3rd party partner.

üîç Key differences between SAP-Managed and Customer-Managed Data Products:

Both types of data products are technically the same, stored in an object store (HDLF), defined using an Open Resource Discover (ORD) JSON files, and published in the data catalog. However let us look at some key differences:

üîç Aspectüü¶ SAP-Managed Data Productsüü© Customer-Managed Data Products
üë®‚Äçüíº Ownership
  • Defined, Owned and Managed by SAP (complete life-cycle)
  • SAP manages data extraction, transformation, load, harmonization.
  • SAP manages metadata, business logic, semantics, associations, schemas and APIs.
  • Owned and Managed by Customer
  • Customer manages metadata, business logic, semantics,associations, schemas and APIs.
üèóÔ∏è CreationDelivered by SAP for SAP LoB ApplicationsBuilt by customers from any SAP/non-SAP data sources
üîÑ UpdatesAutomatically updated by SAP (versioning)Updates controlled by the customer
üß≠ GovernanceFully governed and aligned with SAP standardsGovernance defined by customer policies
üîó ConnectivityReady-to-use with SAP source systems via BDC FormationsUsing SAP Datasphere Native Integrations, SAP BW Data Product Generator 
üóÇÔ∏è Storage LayerSAP BDC FOS (Foundational Service) Layer i.e. HANA Data Lake Files (HDLFs)SAP Datasphere Object Store i.e HANA Data Lake Files (HDLFs)
üîç DiscoverabilityPublished by SAP in Business Accelerator Hub or SAP BDC catalogCustomer need to list and publish it to the catalog.
‚öôÔ∏è Use Cases
  • Best for standard analytics, planning, AI across SAP solutions like SAP S/HANA Cloud (Private/Public).
  • Ready to consume SAP business application data
  • Intelligent Applications are built upon.
  • Custom analytics (non SAP Data)
  • SAP S/4HANA On-premise
  • SAP BW Data Product Generator
  • Unique business logic
  • Extension of Intelligent Applications
  • Local regulations, etc.

 

üì¶What is a Data Package?

Data products are grouped into Data Packages for easier discovery, deployment, and management. A data package may span multiple business domains, such as:  Billing Document,Sales Order, Sales Quotation etc.  This packaging enables users to activate, install and use related data products collectively.

e.g.: Data Package: SAP Sales Data Products (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition), contains multiple data products like Billing Document,Customer Return,Sales Order, Sales Quotation etc. Each data product can be build upon multiple entities e.g. 
Sales Order data product is based on the CDS entities Sales Order(I_SalesOrder) and Sales Order Item(I_SalesOrderItem).

 Where to find more details about SAP Data Products?

Navigate to Business Accelerator Hub -> Data Products -> Select the Product
 
 
Goto API reference for the source API or entities details.

High-level Workflow for the SAP Managed Data Product Activation:

Why use Data Products instead of direct tables for master or transaction raw data?

Unlike raw database tables that are often fragmented, inconsistent, and require heavy lifting for transformation and understanding, Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) provide a ready-to-use, governed, and semantically rich abstraction of the data. These are:

  • Curated and harmonized: Built from SAP S/4HANA and other sources with standardized definitions and business rules.
  • Read-only and analytics-optimized: Designed for high-performance analytical workloads without risk of accidental changes.
  • Easily discoverable via the Data Product Directory and consumable through APIs.
  • Trustworthy: Certified with clear data lineage, ensuring users can rely on them across applications.
  • Reusable and composable: Multiple data products can be combined to build complex models, accelerating time to insights.
  • Enable self-service: Business users can access and explore data without deep technical knowledge, reducing dependency on IT.

By using Data Products, organizations achieve better data consistency, governance, faster decision-making, and agility, which is difficult to achieve with just raw tables.

Why must Data Products be stored on the Object Store (HDLFS) in SAP Business Data Cloud?

Data Products are stored in the object store (HDLFS) to support modern, scalable, and cost-efficient analytics use cases, particularly when dealing with high data volumes. Here's why:

  • Delta Table & Zero-Copy Share Support: Object store enables the use of Delta tables and the Delta Sharing protocol ‚Äî a powerful, open-source mechanism that allows data sharing without copying or moving the data.
  • Efficient Storage via Data Lake: Unlike operational databases like SAP HANA (used for transactional workloads), a data lake is used in analytical environments to reduce storage costs. SAP Business Data Cloud leverages the SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake to store data as efficient files, not traditional tables.
  • Broader Tool Compatibility: File-based storage enables wider integration with various analytical and consumption tools, enhancing flexibility for downstream applications.
  • Scalable and Governed Sharing: With Delta Sharing, Data Products are exposed in a governed, scalable, and open manner, allowing users across the organization to securely consume up-to-date data ‚Äî without duplication or manual transfers.

In short, storing Data Products on the object store ensures low-cost, high-scale, interoperable, and secure data sharing and analytics.

You can learn more about Delta Sharing here: https://delta.io

How to Consume and Activate SAP Managed Data Products ?

  • Activate Data Package.
  • Install Intelligent Application.

 

Summary:

In SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), data products are curated, self-describing packages of business data that replace raw tables with harmonized, analytics-optimized datasets. SAP does the heavy lifting for customers by providing ready-to-use, SAP-managed data products out of the box for all Line of Business applications. This gives customer a trusted and governed data foundation, making it easy to build everything from BI reports to AI models while leveraging cost-effective, scalable storage for high-volume analytics. Happy Learning üôÇ!

Further Resources or References:

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/business-data-cloud 
  • https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/business-data-cloud

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 2: Extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products
entry.content:
Introduction:

In Part 1(SAP Business Data Cloud Series ‚Äì Part 1: Introduction to Data Products) of this blog series, we explored the fundamentals of Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC). Now, in Part 2, we dive into the practical aspect of extending SAP-managed Data Products, specifically, how to incorporate custom Y/Z fields into the standard SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Managed Data Products. If you have already enhanced the underlying CDS views or entities in your SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (PCE) system before activating the corresponding data package or installing the intelligent application, the good news is that your custom fields will automatically flow into the Data Product upon activation. No additional steps required!

In this article, we‚Äôll walk through a common extension scenario involving Sales Order and Billing/Invoice CDS views or SAP Data Products:

 

Data ProductData Source CDS
Sales OrderI_SalesOrder
Sales Order ItemI_SalesOrderItem
Billing Document ItemI_BillingDocumentItemDEX
 

Steps to Extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products Using Key User Extensibility

1. Set Up Adaptation Transport Organizer (ATO): As a prerequisite, ensure ATO is configured to support key user extensions in your system.

2. Add Custom Fields via SAP Fiori App: Open the Custom Fields and Logic app in SAP Fiori and create the required Y/Z custom fields.

How to find business context? Use Tcode: SCFD_REGISTRY

Select Business Context for SD_SALESDOC for Sales Document (Order) and SD_SALESDOCITEM for Sales Document Item.

Similarly  select Business Context SD_BILLINGDOCITEM for Billing Document Item 

Fill the custom field technical details like label, id, data type etc.

3. Publish Custom Fields:After creating the fields, publish them. This step will automatically append your custom fields to the underlying SAP standard ABAP tables.

Publish the field, below one is shown for CampaignID which is added to billing document item.

Likewise it can be done for Sales order (ZZ1_Custom1) and Sales order item (ZZ1_Custom2) custom fields extension.

After above steps custom fields should be appended to standard ABAP tables: VBAK, VBAP and VBRP in our scenario.

VBAK:

 VBAP:

VBRP:

4. Extend the CDS Views or Entities :Enhance the relevant CDS views/entities to include the newly created custom fields.
If the CDS view is listed in the Extensibility Registry (T-code: SCFD_REGISTRY), use Data Source Extensions, this is the recommended approach before resorting to manual CDS view or entity extensions, as demonstrated below.
Alright, we will use CDS extension to include the added and published custom fields:

4.1: Extend CDS View I_SalesOrder to include ZZ_CUSTOM1 field. You can also view the data definitions which got created, when custom fields where published using the Fiori App Custom Fields and Logic.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewAppendName:  'ZEXTSALESORDER'
@EndUserText.label: 'Extension View for I_SalesOrder'
extend view I_SalesOrder with ZEXTEND_SALESORDER
{
ZZ1_Custom1_SDH as ZZ_CUSTOM1
}

Once extension view is activated, you can now test the CDS extractor/view (SE16N):

4.2: Extend CDS View I_SalesOrderItem to include ZZ1_CUSTOM2 field. You can also view in the Eclipse ADT perspective, what CDS extensions have been created for the CDS view, click on the spiral icon.

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewAppendName:  'ZEXTSALESORDITEM'
@EndUserText.label: 'Extension View for I_SalesOrderItem'
extend view I_SalesOrderItem with ZEXTEND_SALESORDERITEM
{
ZZ1_Custom2_SDI as ZZ1_Custom2
}

Click on spiral icon:

4.3: Extend CDS Entity I_BillingDocumentItemDEX to include ZZ_CampaignID field. 
Note: In previous scenarios, we extended CDS views; in this case, we are extending a CDS entity. CDS entity does not have SQL view created.

extend view entity I_BillingDocumentItemDEX with
{
  _Extension.ZZ1_CampaignID_BDI as ZZ_CampaignID

}

5. Validate Data in CDS Views/Entities: Test the extended CDS views to confirm that the custom fields are populated with data (assuming relevant business logic is in place and transactional data has been updated). e.g. For Sales Order extension use released BAdIs enhancement spot ES_SD_SLS_EXTEND, classic ABAP has user-exit MV45AFZZ (this is out of scope for this blog).

In previous using SE16N we validated that fields are populated on the extended views or entities. 

6. Activate the Data Package in the SAP BDC Cockpit :Proceed to activate the related data package that uses the extended CDS views and has data products of interest.
Note: SAP-managed Data products cannot be activated individually. They only can be activated via Intelligent Application or on data package level. That means that all the data products within the data package or Intelligent Application are activated in one step.

Data Package: SAP Sales Data Products( SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition) has the Data Products 1.Sales Order and 2. Billing Documet.

Once you activate the data package, on the SAP S/4HANA side you can check in the Tcode DHADM for subscription, data replication etc.

Transfer jobs overview:

 

APRS is pushing to target HANA Data Lake Files i.e. SAP BDC Foundational services (FOS) layer.

Target HDLF file path:

Give some time based on the data volume of the data products for the data package to become active. 

7. Install the Data Product: Install the SAP-managed data product corresponding to the activated data package.
Currently, Delta-Share or zero-copy works only with Databricks. In SAP Datasphere, these data products are replicated from the FOS layer into the SAP Datasphere Ingestion Space (SAP managed). In the future, SAP Datasphere will also support Delta-Share.

Prerequisite step:  Add space WS_IT so that you can install the data product (via sharing from the system ingestion space).

Next, we will install data products into the SAP Datasphere WS_IT Space (User Modeling Space).
This process creates a data product share from the SAP-managed Ingestion Space to the user-managed WS_IT Space in our scenario.

Go to SAP Datasphere ‚Üí Catalog & Marketplace.

Now, we have successfully installed the Data Products.

8. Preview Data in Local Table: Finally, preview the data within the Data Product‚Äôs local table to confirm that the custom fields are available and populated with the data.
We can view in the WS_IT space, all the data products are installed (shared).

If we click on Billing Document Item data product, then it will navigate to SAP managed Datasphere Ingestion Space RI4400(SAP-Managed).

Great, the data products, now enhanced with your custom (Z) fields, have been successfully installed and are ready for to be used in Datasphere modeling or delta-share with Databricks.

Q: We need to extend an already installed data product. How should we handle this situation?

A: Currently, when you need to extend or change an existing data product, the process On the SAP S/4HANA source side, any changes you make will be handled within the existing framework. On the SAP BDC side, however, you must either deactivate the entire data package or uninstall the intelligent application and then activate or reinstall it to incorporate the new changes to the data product. It is not the most efficient way to handle a small change of adding new field to the data product. The product team is aware of this and is working on a solution to provide more granular control at the data product level, which would allow for more targeted updates in the future.

Summary:

In this blog, we saw how to extend SAP S/4HANA Managed Data Products by adding custom fields and making them available in SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Datasphere. We learned how to use the Custom Fields and Logic app, extend CDS entities, and replicate the updated data by data product activation. Things are improving and getting rapidly in the product, and I will do my best to keep this blog updated with the latest changes. Happy Learning üôÇ!

entry.title: Re: SAP SuccessFactors customer object event driven integ...
entry.content:
Hi @Krisztian2 

There a few factors to consider in achieving that. It is important to know that currently you do not have the possibility to directly trigger Integration Center integrations or external APIs from Business Rules because they do not support outbound API calls or integration triggers. Also note that Intelligent Services Center does not support creating custom events on custom MDF objects.

SAP recommends you build a side-by-side extension on SAP Business Technology Platform that either:

Polls the custom MDF data via the SuccessFactors OData API periodically to enable you detect changes or uses change data capture mechanisms if available. It then publishes events or triggers integrations through SAP Integration Suite Advanced Event Mesh to downstream APIs.

Alternatively, you also have the option to set Integration Center to run on schedules that filters for the changed records and call external APIs accordingly. Once this is completed your integration becomes event-driven at the middleware level rather than directly from SuccessFactors business rules.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: To set up a destination in SAP BTP for connecting to the Microsoft Azure Mail Service -Graph API
entry.content:
1. Access SAP BTP Cockpit 

  • Log into SAP BTP Cockpit: Go to SAP BTP Cockpit 
  • Navigate to Subaccount: In the subaccount of your choice (where the destination will be configured), click on the subaccount to access its settings.

2. Create a New Destination

  • Navigate to Destinations:

    • In the SAP BTP Cockpit, go to Connectivity > Destinations (under the Connectivity section in your subaccount).

    • Create New Destination:

      • Click + (Create New Destination).

      • Fill in the following fields:

3. Configure the Destination for Microsoft Graph API

     Fill in the required fields to define the destination for Microsoft Graph API:

     General Information

  • Name: Choose a descriptive name for the destination, e.g., AzureMailService.

  • Type: Select HTTP.

  • Description: Provide a brief description, e.g., "Destination for Microsoft Graph API to send transactional emails."

  • URL:  https://graph.microsoft.com/V1.0

4. Authentication Settings

  • Authentication:

    • Select OAuth2 for OAuth authentication, since Microsoft Graph API requires OAuth2 Client Credentials flow.

    • OAuth2 Client Credentials: This will be your method for obtaining access tokens to authenticate API requests.

      • OAuth2 Client ID: This is the Client ID from the Azure AD app you registered in the Azure portal.

      • OAuth2 Client Secret: This is the Client Secret generated for the Azure AD app.

      • OAuth2 Token URL: The token URL from Microsoft Identity Platform, which is:

         
        https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenantId}/oauth2/v2.0/token

        Replace {tenantId} with your actual tenant ID.

      • OAuth2 Scope: For sending emails, use the scope Mail.Send. This allows the app to send emails through Microsoft Graph API.

      • OAuth2 Grant Type: Choose Client Credentials as you're using the client credentials flow.

5.Connection Settings

  • URL: Set the URL to connect to Microsoft Graph API. The base URL for Microsoft Graph is:

     
    https://graph.microsoft.com

  • Proxy Type: If you are using a proxy, you can set it here. If not, leave it as None.

  • Additional Headers: You can add any extra headers if needed. Usually, for Microsoft Graph API, no additional headers are required apart from the authorization header, which is handled automatically by the OAuth2 configuration.

6. Test the Destination

  • Test Connectivity: After creating the destination, test it by clicking on Check Connection.

  • Successful Connection: If the connection is successful, you‚Äôll see a message confirming that the destination is reachable.

7. Secure the Destination

  • Security Considerations:

    • Make sure that only authorized users and applications have access to this destination.

    • You can use Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to limit who can access this destination in SAP BTP.

8. Integrate the Destination into Your Application

Once the destination is configured, you can integrate it into your Node.js or CAPM application to use it for sending emails.

  • Access Destination Programmatically:

    const { retrieveJwt } = require('@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity');
    const { executeHttpRequest } = require('@sap-cloud-sdk/http-client');
    module.exports = srv => {
      srv.on('sendmail', async (req) => {
            const JWT_Token = retrieveJwt(req);    // Access the destination via JWT Secured token
        const destination = {
          destinationName: 'AzureMailService', JWT_Token
         };
      }
    }

Use Destination in API Requests: Use the executeHttpRequest method from the SAP Cloud SDK to make requests to the Microsoft Graph API, passing in the destination to authenticate the request.

Conclusion

By setting up a destination for the Microsoft Azure Mail Service in SAP BTP, you establish a secure and centralized way for your SAP applications to send transactional emails via the Microsoft Graph API. This eliminates the need for third-party email services, reduces costs, and ensures a reliable and scalable email service across your BTP landscape.

entry.title: Re: SF Concurrent Employment - Custom MDF
entry.content:
Hi @MM012 

Thank you for your question. In reference to your client‚Äôs scenario, below you will find a summarized information and guidance which are based on SAP SuccessFactors best practices:

First, it is important to know that for employees that hold truly distinct positions with different attributes, SAP SuccessFactors fully supports this via the native concurrent employment feature. Each employment is available as a separate record with its own user ID and timesheet. This ensures you have the option for proper tracking, payroll, and organisation chart accuracy.

However, for employees with multiple positions or locations that share the same key position attributes, please note that the standard concurrent employment model tends to create many positions, profiles, and also timesheets. Therefore, it increases the process complexity.

Therefore, some organizations often explore the use of a custom MDF object to track multiple locations or sub-positions under a single employment. This reduces the number of profiles and timesheets. While this can simplify user experience and reduce position count, you will have to consider the following:

    • Custom MDF objects do not natively integrate with standard SAP modules like Time Management, Payroll, Recruiting, and Onboarding.
    • There is a possibility that the cause integration, reporting, or upgrade challenges.
    • Workflow and process automation tied to standard employment and position objects might not trigger on custom MDF data.

Which means, thorough impact analysis involving EC, Time, Payroll, Recruiting, and Integration teams is crucial before you decide to use custom MDF for concurrent employment scenarios.

It is often advisable to use standard concurrent employment for truly separate positions and consider custom MDF enhancements only for supplementary tracking, not as a full replacement.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

Concurrent Employment

Enabling Concurrent Employment in Employee Central

Adding a Concurrent Employment

entry.title: Re: Able to Schedule Dates on Weekends (Make Parts - MRP...
entry.content:
Hi @Marco_Antonio_R 

To enable SAP to schedule Production Orders and Planned Orders on weekends, there a few things you must put in place. You have already set your Factory Calendar to 7-day working which is the right step. You now need do the following:

First, make sure the desired Work Center has the same factory calendar assigned, which must include weekend days. The reason is, this calendar has higher priority for scheduling production operations.

Then, confirm that your desired shift sequence and capacity settings in the Work Center covers weekends.

To run the MRP, ensure that the Planning Calendar assigned to the material or plant includes weekends as well. This calendar controls the MRP‚Äôs planned order generation dates.

Finally, you need to verify routing and scheduling profiles to confirm there is no exclusion of weekends in the configuration.

Once you have succeded in aligning all these points, both your Production Orders and MRP Planned Orders will be scheduled to start and finish on weekends if capacity and demand justify it.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Incorrect Pricing Condition Assigned During EDI Sales...
entry.content:
Hello @smimid 

Thanks for your detailed message and for sharing the EDI payload, that‚Äôs very helpful.

From your description, it appears the system is defaulting to the ZPS0 pricing condition, typically used for intercompany sales, instead of ZPR0, which is appropriate for your standard EDI sales orders. This usually points to a problem with the underlying pricing procedure determination logic or condition record setup.

Below are the recommended checks

Sales Document Type

  • Confirm which document type is being triggered via the EDI inbound interface.
  • If it‚Äôs an intercompany sales document (or one linked to an intercompany process), it might be linked to a pricing procedure that includes ZPS0 by default.

Pricing Procedure Determination

The system determines pricing based on a combination of:

Sales area

  • Document pricing procedure (from the sales doc type)
  • Customer pricing procedure (from the sold-to party)
  • You can review this under SSCUI 102429 ‚Äì Set Pricing Procedure Determination.
  • Check which pricing procedure is currently assigned, and verify whether it includes ZPR0 or ZPS0.

Condition Records

If both ZPR0 and ZPS0 exist in the pricing procedure, the system will pick the one with a valid and more specific condition record.

Use the Set Condition Records ‚Äì Sales app (F1873) to check whether ZPS0 is maintained for the material/customer combination, while ZPR0 might not be.

EDI Input

Since your payload doesn‚Äôt include condition type segments (e.g. E1EDP05 with KSCHL), the system is relying fully on backend logic  which makes configuration accuracy even more critical.

Next Steps:

  • Check the sales document type and its assigned pricing procedure.
  • Ensure that ZPR0 is included and prioritized correctly.
  • Review condition records to confirm ZPR0 is maintained for the relevant materials/customers.

Best regards,
Chuma


GenAI Assisted Content SAP useful documentations
(SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition | Sales & Distribution)

entry.title: Re: Cria√ß√£o de POs via requisi√ß√£o duplicando devido grupo...
entry.content:
Hello @EmersonRancoletta 

You're right; after implementing SP10, the system began dividing Purchase Orders by Purchase Group during the conversion from Purchase Requisitions. This modification is outlined in SAP Note 3171484, which details the Split Criteria for PO creation from Purchase Requisition.

The note states that whether line items share the same purchase group value can be customised. However, from SP10 and later versions, the presence and position of this setting may vary depending on system configuration and updates.

Recommended steps:

Check Customising in SPRO
In your SAP system, go to:

  • SPRO ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Order ‚Üí Define Split Criteria for PO Creation
  • If EKGRP (Purchase Group) is listed, you can deselect it to prevent splitting by Purchase Group.

Check for Active BAdIs

  • If the option is not available in customisation, review whether BAdIs like ME_PUR_SPLIT_CRITERIA are active and enforcing the split.
  • If neither applies, raise an OSS incident with SAP referencing SAP Note 3171484 and request guidance for your release.

Best regards,
Chuma

GenAI Assisted Content
References

  • 3171484 - Why did a requisition split into multiple purchase orders? 
  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Define Split Criteria for PO Creation
    FAQ KB0392569

entry.title: Re: Need to get option of changing status of Notification...

entry.title: Re: API Inbound Delivery SAP_COM_0224 API Error deliveryr...
entry.content:
Hello @Phil_P 

Thanks for sharing the detailed error log ‚Äî it helps narrow down the issue. Based on the messages (VersionMismatch, document not wellformed, and SRT: Authorization denied), there are three key areas to check:

SOAP Version Alignment
The error ‚ÄúWrong SOAP Version‚Äù happens if the envelope namespace doesn‚Äôt match the Content-Type header.

SOAP 1.1: Use http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/ with header Content-Type: text/xml; charset=UTF-8 and SOAPAction: "".

SOAP 1.2: Use http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope with header Content-Type: application/soap+xml; charset=UTF-8.
Mixing these will trigger the version mismatch.

XML Well-Formedness & Namespaces
The ‚Äú?> expected‚Äù and ‚Äúundeclared namespace prefix‚Äù errors indicate either a stray BOM/whitespace before <?xml ‚Ä¶?> or inconsistent prefix usage (soapenv: in <Envelope> but soap: in <Header>/<Body>).

Ensure you declare all prefixes (edi, soap/soapenv) at the <Envelope> level.

Remove any hidden BOM characters and keep UTF-8 encoding without BOM.

Authorization & Communication Arrangement
The ‚ÄúAuthorization denied‚Äù means the inbound user in Communication Arrangement SAP_COM_0224 is either missing or not used for authentication. Please check that:

The inbound service Create Inbound Delivery is active.

A Communication User is assigned to the arrangement for inbound calls.

The credentials used in SoapUI match that user and are sent as Basic Auth (preemptively).

For testing, I recommend starting with the minimal working SOAP 1.1 request below to rule out XML and namespace issues:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"
xmlns:edi="http://sap.com/xi/EDI">
<soapenv:Header/>
<soapenv:Body>
<edi:DeliveryRequest>
<MessageHeader>
<ID>42F2E9AFC5FF1EDA8E8ECA88E76A43AA</ID>
<CreationDateTime>2025-08-08T12:00:00Z</CreationDateTime>
<SenderBusinessSystemID>EXTSYS</SenderBusinessSystemID>
<RecipientBusinessSystemID>S4HC</RecipientBusinessSystemID>
</MessageHeader>
</edi:DeliveryRequest>
</soapenv:Body>
</soapenv:Envelope>

Once this is accepted, you can extend it with your full delivery payload. Also, you can monitor the inbound call in the Message Monitoring app to confirm whether it fails at parsing or authorization.

Please give this a try and let me know your findings ‚Äî especially if the minimal request still triggers the same error. We can then focus on the specific step that‚Äôs blocking you.

Kind regards,

Chuma

  • GenAI Assistance content
  • Reference:
  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì SAP_COM_0224 Communication Arrangement
  •  Inbound Delivery ‚Äì Create (B2B) API Documentation
  •  SOAP Versioning ‚Äì W3C Specification

entry.title: Re: Print: General Correspondence App form formatting in...
entry.content:
Hello @charlene2 

Thank you for providing the screenshots. After reviewing your question, I found that the loss of line breaks in the Print: General Correspondence output occurs because the form field in the standard template is set to plain text. In this mode, any formatting from the Text Editor tab is ignored during rendering.

To preserve your formatting in the print preview, you have the following options:

Enable Rich Text (XHTML) in the Form Template

  • Adapt the template in Maintain Form Templates, so the text field is set to Rich Text. This ensures your manual line breaks and spacing are printed as entered.

Use Break Tags

  • If template changes aren‚Äôt possible, insert  <br/>  where you want line breaks, provided the form logic interprets them.

Reference a Standard Text

  • Maintain your correspondence text as a standard text (SO10) with paragraph formatting, then reference it in the correspondence.

In your case, the first option is the most reliable and will ensure consistent formatting across all outputs.

Let me know if it helps

Kind regards,

Chuma

 

  • GenAI assistance content
  • References Maintaining Form Templates for the Manage Collections Emails App

entry.title: Re: How do you access country-dependent fields in BP mast...
entry.content:
Hello @TF0126 

You‚Äôre right, in SAP S/4HANA Public cloud, country-specific BP fields like Payment Terms Shift (found under the country tab in the BP UI) are not accessible through the public Business Partner API or most standard CDS views. These fields reside in dependent tables that are not included in the released public data model.

Current options in Public Cloud:

Check the released CDS views

    • Use the View Browser app to search for released data sources, for example I_BusinessPartner, I_BusinessPartnerCompany, I_BusinessPartnerBank
    • If the country-dependent table containing your field is released, you can build a Custom CDS View to join it with your BP master view.

Field extensibility

    • If the field is available in the underlying structure but not exposed, you can try extending a released CDS view or API via the Custom Fields and Logic app.
    • For country-dependent tables not released to the public cloud extensibility layer, this option will not be possible

Raise a request to SAP

    • If the field is business-critical (like Payment Terms Shift), log an incident or submit a request via the Customer Influence portal, asking SAP to expose the field in a public API or released CDS view.

Currently, if the field is neither in a released view nor available for extension, the only way to access it is via the UI or with SAP's permission.

 

With regards

Chuma

 

  • GenAI Assist content
  • SAP Useful documentation references
  • SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Business Partner APIs
  • Custom Fields and Logic ‚Äì Extending APIs
  • SAP Continuous Influence for SAP S/4HANA Cloud,

entry.title: EWM-TM Integration: Clean Core alternative to unreleased BAdI in S/4HANA PCE
entry.content:
Hey community,

I'm implementing EWM with TM in S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition and hitting a Clean Core compliance issue.

Scenario: When TM is active in the system and I try to process goods issue in EWM (transaction /SCWM/PRDO), I get this error:

/SCWM/LK202 ‚Äì TU for delivery assignment &1 / &2 not found

This happens because when TM is configured, the system automatically sets TRANSPL_TYPE = 'C' (when TMS_PLAN_IND = 'X'), which means EWM expects a Transportation Unit before allowing the goods issue. This blocks the entire outbound process.

Standard solution (blocked in PCE)
Note 3084918 addresses this - implement BAdI /SCWM/EX_ERP_MAPIN_OD_SAVEREPL and in method MAPIN, clear the field TRANSPL_TYPE in structure MT_DLV_REQUEST-s_head-t_transport.

The logic is simple and it works perfectly in on-premise systems. But here's the problem: in S/4HANA PCE with ABAP Cloud, the ATC check fails:

Error: Usage of not released application API: /SCWM/IF_EX_MAPIN_OD_SAVEREPL
Code: CHKC_IFACE_NOT_RELEASED

Can't transport this to production as it violates Clean Core principles.

What I've Tried
Looked for alternative BAdIs that might have access to TRANSPL_TYPE - no luck
Checked if there's any customizing to prevent the default 'C' value - nothing found
Searched for released APIs in the same process - all the relevant ones are unreleased
Tried to find workarounds in /SCWM/TU (called internally by /SCWM/PRDO) - same restrictions

Questions for the Community
Is there a released BAdI or API that allows modifying TRANSPL_TYPE in this EWM-TM scenario?
Any configuration trick to prevent the system from defaulting to transport type 'C' when TM is active?
Has anyone solved this in a Clean Core compliant way? Maybe a different approach I'm not seeing?
Does SAP have plans to release this BAdI for cloud environments? It seems like a standard requirement for EWM-TM integration.
This is becoming a blocker for the go-live. The functionality works great with the BAdI, but I need a solution that passes ATC checks.

Will definitely post the solution here once I find it. Thanks in advance!

Technical Details:

S/4HANA PCE 2023
Transaction: /SCWM/PRDO (Outbound Delivery Order)
Error occurs during goods issue processing
ABAP Cloud with strict ATC enforcement

entry.title: Re: Showing wrong attachment document in SAP MM
entry.content:
Hi @pratik_soni6 

Thank you for raising this issue. I will walk you through it.

Reading your explanation, it describes a common issue often faced while trying to attach mismatched files. Please be aware that the problem you described is typically caused by issues such as attachment file naming, mapping logic in the integration layer, or configuration in Ariba which then affects how attachments are linked to created Purchase Orders.

SAP recommends that you do the following:

First, ensure every Purchase Order attachment has a unique, clearly defined filename. This must be without blank spaces or restricted characters and must not exceed 50 characters in its length.

Then, confirm that the parameters to export attachments or comments to SAP ERP are enabled in your Ariba system.

Please ensure to review and correct your integration or middleware mapping rules to guarantee the actual file sent from Ariba is the one linked and stored against the Purchase Order in SAP.

Finally, ensure to test the process by uploading uniquely named documents and verify if the linkage is correct.

Should the issue persist, I would advice to escalate to SAP support for deeper payload and mapping troubleshooting.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Preferential origin not determined on invoice
entry.content:
Hi @Pranjal09689p97 

Hi

Reviewing the details you provided on the issue with invoice 99148879 for material ABC, where the preferential origin is showing as ‚ÄúNo‚Äù despite shipment from plant 1001 and production in plant 1004, here are a few considerations I suggest to help you better understand the situation and a possible positive outcome

Potential root cause of the issue:

It is important to note that in SAP ECC, preferential origin confirmation depends on a few factors such as the plant, your master data settings, BOM, supplier declarations, and your defined threshold rules in the shipping plant.

Even if the production plant meets the defined threshold requirement, the origin status may not be transferred or confirmed in the shipping plant unless relevant master data, preference calculation, and cross-plant data transfer are correctly set up.

If the defined preference is correctly determined in the master data but still displays incorrectly, the invoice output program or the form logic may not be pulling the right field.

I would recommend you take these steps:

  • First, ensure to verify material master Foreign Trade or Export Data for both plants 1001 and 1004. This ensures that origin and preference indicators are populated.
  • Then ensure BOM and supplier declarations are complete and transferred to the shipping plant in the cross-plant scenarios.
  • Make sure to check your defined preference determination configuration so that origin status from 1004 is recognized and applied when shipping from 1001.
  • Thereafter, make sure to confirm threshold comparison logic is using data from the correct plant.
  • Finally, if determination is correct but invoice still shows ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù debug the invoice output form or program to ensure preferential origin is read from the correct source.

The issue here is likely master data or configuration in preference determination, not just purely related to the invoice output. If standard logic does not support this cross-plant scenario, an enhancement or BAdI implementation may be required to help you solve the issue.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

Preference Statements

Preference Determination

entry.title: Re: SAP IBP object imported into Q or P tenant - how do I...
entry.content:
Hi @contovhal 

Thank you for your question.

The simple answer is no. However, there are a few things to note.

In the current standard SAP IBP, there is no ‚ÄúCreated On‚Äù or ‚ÄúImported On‚Äù date field for business roles or similar objects. The system only shows the Changed On date. This reflects the last modification, not the initial import or creation time.

If a role is not part of any software collection, there is unfortunately no standard way to find out when it was first imported into the tenant. The system does not provide an audit history or log for initial creation in the standard UI or reporting features.

Here are potential workarounds for your use case:

  • First, make use of external governance or identity management tools. e.g., SAP Identity Governance to track creation events if integrated.
  • Then, maintain manual logs when importing or creating new roles in the tenant for the required future reference.

To summarize, the information you are looking for isn‚Äôt available directly in IBP, and tracking must be done via external tools or manual processes in the future.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Fiori App 1704 run outbound process - missing details
entry.content:
Hi @Dirk_Kaestingschaefer 

Thank you for your question. I will walk you through it.

To see the block reason for blocked outbound deliveries in the details screen of the Run Outbound Process app, here are a few considerations and facts.

It is important to note that by default, the block reason (delivery block code) is maintained in SAP ERP/S4 and it controls blocking at delivery header or item level. However, be aware that standard outbound delivery apps which includes those in IBP or warehouse execution do not always display the block reason field in their User Interface with the out-of-the-box solution.

For the required information to be shown, here a few facts that must be in place:

  • The underlying data source which can be the CDS view or OData service used by the outbound delivery details UI must include the delivery block reason field.
  • If those are not present, a backend CDS view or UI extension is needed to expose and display this field.
  • SAP provides standard CDS views for delivery block reasons that can be leveraged for such UI enhancements.

I recommend coordinating with your SAP technical team or UI developers to extend the outbound delivery details screen and include delivery block and block reason information for full visibility.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

Sales Order Outbound Delivery Scenario

entry.title: Re: EWM-TM Integration: Clean Core alternative to unrelea...
entry.content:
Hi @wguedex 

Based on the information you provided regarding your query on the Clean Core compliance issue during EWM‚ÄìTM integration in S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (PCE), there are a few things to highlight. I will provide a summary of the described situation and guidance on potential next steps:

Here are a few SAP Clean Core compliant confirmed Facts

There is no released BAdI or API currently existing in PCE to modify TRANSPL_TYPE during this process without you violating the defined Clean Core rules.

There is also no standard customizing option available to help you prevent defaulting to 'C' when TM is active.

Please note that using unreleased APIs in PCE is prohibited by SAP policy and fails mandatory ATC checks. The current default system design expects a TU for goods issue when TM is active.

This is what I suggest you do:

  • There is currently no known information if SAP intents to the BAdI for cloud environments. Therefore, I suggest you consider raising an SAP incident explaining the critical blocking issue and request either:
  • A Release of the relevant BAdI, or an alternative Clean Core‚Äëcompliant solution.
  • Review your TM‚ÄëEWM configuration to ensure TU creation is triggered early enough to avoid the block from happening.
  • You can also consider side‚Äëby‚Äëside enhancements via SAP BTP for non‚Äëinvasive process handling.

At present, this approach is the only way i think you could resolve the issue while remaining fully SAP‚Äëcompliant.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: o Add New Service Call Type in SAP FSM Connected to S...
entry.content:
Hello @Simon_Lehnert 

When FSM is connected to S/4HANA Public Cloud, Service Call Types are derived from Service Order Types in S/4HANA and cannot be created directly within FSM.

Possible solution steps are below

  1. Go to Manage Your Solution -Configure Your Solution.
  2. Application Area: Service Management.
  3. Use SSCUI 103751 (Define Service Order Types) to create the new type.
  4. Save and activate.
  5. Run Master Data Synchronisation in FSM to pull the new type across.

SAP Useful Reference below

  • Service Order Types ‚Äì S/4HANA Cloud Help
  • FSM Service Call Settings

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to fetch fields from multiple successfactor odata...
entry.content:
Hello @yashsap1 

For your requirement to extract ~133 fields across 20 SuccessFactors EC entity sets in a single iFlow, the most efficient approach is to use the Compound Employee (SFAPI) interface instead of making multiple OData GET calls.

When an Employee is Compounded

  • Returns a single, consolidated XML payload covering PerPerson, PerPersonal, EmpJob, Position, PerNationalId, email, and more.
  • Supports full or delta mode, reducing processing time and API calls.
  • Natively supported by the CPI SuccessFactors (SFAPI) adapter.
  • Simplifies mapping since all required segments are delivered together, avoiding $expand or $batch limitations in OData.

Suggested next steps:

  1. Enable and test the Compound Employee API in your SuccessFactors provisioning.
  2. Configure CPI to consume CE data via the SFAPI adapter.
  3. Map the XML segments to your target 133-field layout and deliver via SFTP.

Best regards,
Chuma

  • SAP Useful references
  • Introduction to the CompoundEmployee API-SAP Help

entry.title: Re: To set up a destination in SAP BTP for connecting to...
entry.content:
Hello @soujanya_vanteru_ 

For your requirement to connect SAP BTP to Microsoft Graph API for sending emails via Azure, please find the verified configuration steps below. This setup has been tested to work with the Client Credentials OAuth 2.0 flow.

1. Azure AD Configuration

Register an application in Azure AD.

Assign Application permission Mail.Send (and Mail.Send.Shared if needed).

Grant Admin Consent for these permissions.

2. SAP BTP Destination Configuration
In your BTP subaccount:

Name: AzureMailService

Type: HTTP

URL: https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0

ProxyType: Internet

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

tokenServiceURL: https://login.microsoftonline.com/<tenant-id>/oauth2/v2.0/token

clientId: <your-client-id>

clientSecret: <your-client-secret>

scope: https://graph.microsoft.com/.default

tokenServiceURLType: Dedicated

3. Sending Emails
With Application permissions, use:

POST /v1.0/users/{senderUPN}/sendMail

Where {senderUPN} is the mailbox you are authorized to send from.

Example payload:

{
"message": {
"subject": "Test from SAP BTP",
"body": { "contentType": "HTML", "content": "<p>Hello!</p>" },
"toRecipients": [{ "emailAddress": { "address": "recipient@domain.com" } }]
},
"saveToSentItems": true
}

4. Programmatic Access (Node.js/CAP)

import { executeHttpRequest } from '@sap-cloud-sdk/http-client';
import { retrieveJwt } from '@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity';

srv.on('sendmail', async (req) => {
const jwt = retrieveJwt(req);
const payload = { /* see JSON above */ };
await executeHttpRequest(
{ destinationName: 'AzureMailService', jwt },
{ method: 'POST', url: '/users/sender@domain.com/sendMail', data: payload }
);
});

5. Testing
Note: ‚ÄúCheck Connection‚Äù in Destinations only verifies reachability. Test with a real Graph call (e.g., GET /v1.0/$metadata) to confirm token issuance and permissions.

Best regards,

Chuma

  • GenAI Assist content
  • Reference:

Microsoft Graph API ‚Äì Send Mail

SAP BTP Destination Service ‚Äì OAuth2 Client Credentials

entry.title: Re: Attribute Transformations with SAP Integrated Busines...
entry.content:
Hi @SaiKiran9 

Thank you for walking me through your setup and providing the screenshots which provided a good detail on what the case might be. Based on those details, here is what I think might be causing the problem you are facing:

The defined time profile tied to your new planning level might not include all the PERIODID attributes you expect especially if daily or offset levels are missing.

Please note, in IBP, the Attribute Transformation framework only shows PERIODIDs that are available in the active time profile which is used by both the base and the target planning levels.

If there is any mismatch between the time profile levels of ZDAYPRODCUST and ZDAYPRODCUSTNEW, that could be the reason why you are not seeing the transformations you need. I suggest you carry out the following:

Ensure that both planning levels are linked to the same, or at least compatible time profiles. The profiles should include all relevant levels such as Day, Technical Week, Week, Month, Quarter, Year.

Make sure all the PERIODID attributes you need are active and available in your time profile configuration.

After confirming the time profiles line up between source and target, then make sure to re-try the Attribute Transformation setup and see if the full list of PERIODIDs appears.

If you‚Äôre still hitting a wall, consider creating a dedicated time profile for your transformation process that contains every intermediate level, and link it to both planning levels.

Once you have concluded these steps, i advice to try building your Attribute Transformation key figure again. With the right time profiles, you should see the complete set of PERIODID options.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP ERP, Private Edition, Transition Option: What Does it Mean for You as a Healthcare Customer?
entry.content:
Challenges in this ECO system:

  • High initial cost & ROI uncertainty ‚Äì Many healthcare providers, especially smaller hospitals, hesitate due to large upfront investment with unclear short-term returns.

  • Complex customisation needs ‚Äì Healthcare processes are often unique, requiring heavy system tailoring, which increases project time and risk.

  • Integration with legacy systems ‚Äì Many hospitals still rely on older EMR, LIS, and billing systems, making smooth integration a technical and operational hurdle.

  • Change management & user adoption ‚Äì Hospital staff may resist switching from familiar tools to SAP, especially under tight schedules.

  • Regulatory & localisation challenges ‚Äì Ensuring the system meets healthcare-specific legal, insurance, and data standards in different regions can delay implementation.

  • Limited peer references ‚Äì With fewer live healthcare case studies, it‚Äôs harder for new adopters to benchmark best practices or learn from proven implementations.

In short, while SAP ERP Private Edition Transition Option offers a longer runway and stability, the healthcare sector still needs stronger training networks, more localised support, and proven adoption roadmaps to make the transition smoother.

entry.title: Re: How to change existing hierarchy in PRODHS fields acc...
entry.content:
Hello @markus_rietmann3 

SAP Note 1070939 recommends naming the initial three PRODHS fields as PRODH1‚Äì3 (without the ZZ prefix) to ensure compatibility with standard programs. However, renaming these now would disrupt dozens of generated SD condition tables, so making a direct change isn‚Äôt feasible.

If the only concern is the ABAP test class, a safer method is to create a small mapping structure with PRODH1‚Äì3 populated from your ZZ fields. Use it where the standard expects the original names. Most customers in this situation keep the ZZ fields as they are and only create mappings when necessary.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Understanding ABAP Pipeline Engine used for Data Integration in Datasphere
entry.content:
@Martin_Kuma , Thank you for your input.
To clarify, I‚Äôm referring to an SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system in this context. As I mentioned in my previous comment, in our case we are using SDI (Smart Data Integration) via DP Agent and Using Remote Table for Real Time Replications from S4 Hana to Datasphere. When I mention Buffer Table, I specifically mean the RDB (Resilient Data Buffer).

So I don‚Äôt fully agree with your  statement that *ODQDATA, *_C, _F are the buffer tables where the logging tables post to. Remote tables cannot use ODQ, only if wrapped into CDS with CDC. 

Subscriber Logging Tables  post to the RDB as well, not just ODQDATA or its related tables.
RDB, which serves as the actual buffer in many scenarios (example Replication flow &  Data Flow in SAP Datasphere) .

entry.title: Re: SAP AVC Need to update the Bom qnty based on characte...
entry.content:
Hello @ankit_1662 

To update a BOM component‚Äôs quantity in AVC based on a characteristic:

Put the dependency rule directly on the BOM item.

Use a numeric characteristic (AVC_ANCHO) with the same unit as the BOM component.

Example AVC rule:

  • QUANTITY = quantity( AVC_ANCHO - 0.03, 'M' )
  • For classic LO-VC:
  • $SELF.QUANTITY = ( AVC_ANCHO - 0.03 )

Ensure the production version uses this BOM, and the characteristic is unit-compatible.

Describing the Advanced Variant Configuration (AVC Product Configuration)-SAP Learning 

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Story Report with Direct Reports AND Salary with Acti...
entry.content:
Hello @carlyhilder71 

The multiplication happens because the acting-pay row is duplicated for every direct report. When your Salary with Acting Pay is calculated using SUM, it ends up counting the same acting pay multiple times.

Data are aggregated per employee prior to grouping by rows in the cross tab.

  1. Create two Restricted Measures (or calculated columns in the model):
  • Annual Salary (pay comp = base)
  • Annual Acting Pay (pay comp = acting)

For each measure set:

  • Aggregation: Sum
  • Exception Aggregation: Sum
  • Exception Aggregation Dimension: Employee (Employee ID)
      1. Calculated measure:
        Salary with Acting Pay = Annual Salary + Annual Acting Pay
        Give it the same Exception Aggregation (by Employee).
        2. For direct reports, apply 'Count Distinct' to (Direct Report User ID) filtered by employee class = employee. Do not add 'Direct Report' as a row dimension; show it only as a measure.

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Help me for c_ts452 question
entry.content:
A document parking can be used:

Account assignment information is missing for a purchase order item
Account assignment information is missing for an invoice item.

Why not the others?

  • EDI invoice containing variances. This usually triggers an error or holds for invoice verification, not parking.

  • Goods receipt posted for an item needing quality inspection ‚Üí This is handled via the QM (Quality Management) process, not by parking a document.

So, the correct answers are:
2 and 3.
